executive_summary: According to data from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA), the number of honey-producing colonies in the Beekeeping industry in the US has decreased slightly in 2022 by 1.1%. Despite shrinking production volumes due to reduced farm and consumer demand, honey prices exhibited a 12.0% increase in 2022. A sharp rebound in consumer demand for agriculture products sparked increased demand from farms for pollination services. According to the USDA, which started collecting data on pollination services in 2015, revenue from that segment has supported industry revenue growth, until 2020 when it exhibited a 17.5% decline, causing industry revenue to fall 11.7% in 2020 alone. Reduced demand for pollination services caused industry revenue to decline 10.3% in 2022. Industry revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 6.7% over the past five years, and is expected to reach $624.2 million in 2023. This includes a 1.2% increase in 2023 as farm demand for pollination services continues to increase driven by consumer demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: US Beekeepers Have Begun to Report Unusually High Losses of Hives
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Originally thought to be a part of standard winter die-offs, the phenomenon has been dubbed colony collapse disorder (CCD). About half of all affected colonies demonstrated symptoms inconsistent with any known causes of honeybee death, where a colony's worker bee population abruptly disappears, with very few dead bees located near the colony. This has wiped out much of the domestic capacity for honey production in the United States, which was an estimated 3.0 million hives in the early 1990s, dropped to a low of 2.3 million hives in 2008, and has stayed low at an estimated 2.7 million hives in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: There is Limited Competition From Imports Due to Tariffs and Trade Agreements
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite import tariffs on honey, this industry experiences a high level of import competition. Nearly $500.0 million in illegal honey imports from China, while a surge in 2021 comes as a result of the increased import competition from Argentina. Overall, since industry products are priced in cents per pound, percent swings in industry trade values tend to be wide.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Low-cost foreign alternatives are more attractive to downstream food and beverage producers.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Imports were on the decline due to strong domestic production and flagging domestic demand, though these conditions reversed in 2020. It is important to recall that since industry products are priced in cents per pound, trade values tend to swing rapidly on a year-over-year basis. The United States no longer imports large volumes of honey from China, primarily due to the restriction of imports through imposing higher tariffs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: POLLINATION SERVICES HAVE GROWN AS A PRODUCT SEGMENT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: US beekeepers have increased their sales to other farmers within the agricultural sector over the past five years, reflecting honey producers' shift to serve the pollination services market. Rather than competing with lower-priced imports, many operators have focused on sourcing bees to crop farmers for pollination purposes. The USDA estimates that bees add about $15.0 billion in value to US crop production every year. For example, almond trees are entirely reliant on honeybees for pollination. Due to the rising cost of pollination services and a rising price of honey, industry profit is expected to remain relatively high.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Factors that interfere with beekeepers' operations
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Unpredictable weather patterns will continue to affect revenue, as is the case with most agricultural industries. Since honey farmers do not receive government price subsidies, revenue and profit remain volatile. The possibility of disease is just as likely. Colony collapse disorder (CCD) is still expected to be a determining factor in the volume of honey production in the United States and the average price at which it sells.

Any outbreak, either domestically or internationally, may lead to unprecedented industry volatility. It's difficult to anticipate future pollination needs, though it is expected that pollination services will continue increasing.

Beekeeping and honey production hold potential for many developing countries. It is highly labor-intensive, so countries with low wages can produce honey at relatively low costs. Imports, especially from India and Argentina, pose a major threat to domestic production. Industry wages are expected to continue growing. As costs increase for US honey producers, domestic prices are expected to rise, and as a result, downstream food and beverage manufacturers are expected to increasingly source lower-priced imports.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Lower-cost imports expected for food processors
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) generally protects domestic farming industries through quotas and similar import-restricting programs. Due to the high price of US honey, the export market is expected to remain weak. Despite a projected depreciation of the dollar making US exports somewhat more affordable on the international market, exports are expected to stagnate and slowly decline in the next few years.

As a result of international competition, industry establishments may turn to new or niche products. High-quality and high-value honey will help honey producers differentiate themselves. An increasing focus on healthy and organic food products will likely drive demand for naturally made honey, opening a door for US producers. According to the USDA, organic crop farming has much to gain by using bees for pollination services, which will likely increase demand.

The use of bee products in medicine may also influence demand for the industry's products over the next five years. Propolis, a resinous mixture used to seal hives, is used in a variety of natural medicines, including antibiotics, dentists' antiplaque agents and antitumor growth agents. Research into the properties of propolis may discover new uses for the product.

The growth of agricultural industries, such as fruit and nuts, is expected to lead to higher demand for bee pollination purposes. More specifically, the almond crop in California is forecast to expand, and because almond farmers are some of the biggest users of outsourced pollination services and pay the highest price for these services, a renewed demand is expected to boost prices for bees. As more beekeepers move to service pollination needs, more operators are expected to enter the industry.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry raise bees. They collect and gather honey and sell bees, royal jelly, beeswax, propolis, pollen, venom and other bee products.

threats: Per capita sugar and sweetener consumption

key_trends: The Beekeeping industry raises bees and gathers honey, while also selling bee, pollen and other products.
Similar to much of the Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting sector, the Beekeeping industry is influenced by weather patterns, import competition and the threat of disease outbreak.
The Beekeeping industry is not expected to experience much structural change over the five years to 2028.
Industry revenue is anticipated to fall as a result of lower consumer demand decreasing need for pollination services.
Regulation of the Beekeeping industry generally occurs at the state level.
Among other things, state-run departments of agriculture operate apiary inspection programs.
Due to deteriorating trade relations with China, both the United States and China have imposed higher import tariffs on honey.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Processors sell honey to downstream retailers, food service industries and food manufacturing industries.
Producers also sell their honey, combs or beeswax directly to consumers through farmers' markets, roadside stands or supermarkets.
Other markets include brokers or dealers that contact a bottler and organize the distribution of the honey.

products_and_services.product_description: Honey is purchased directly by food manufacturers as an ingredient in other food products, and also by consumers.
Bee colonies are rented to farmers for pollination purposes, particularly for crops like almonds, alfalfa, carrots and pumpkins.

tier_1_suppliers: Coal & Natural Gas Power in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US
Plant & Flower Growing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Farm Supplies Wholesaling in the US
Flower & Nursery Stock Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Snack Food Production in the US
Seasoning, Sauce and Condiment Production in the US
Syrup & Flavoring Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Per Capita Sugar and Sweetener Consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita sugar and sweetener consumption drives industry revenue up. As consumption of sugar and sweeteners, including syrups, such as honey, increases, demand for industry products rises as well.

The volume of agricultural production of crops in the United States influences the number of bees required for pollination. When crop production increases, demand for bees for pollination also increases.

Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. As honey is typically more expensive than traditional sugar products and corn syrups, an increase in consumers' disposable income typically enables them to better afford industry products.

As the US dollar appreciates, imports of honey become less expensive domestically. When it depreciates, imports become more expensive, making downstream producers rely more heavily on the domestic product.

Sugar and honey are both sweeteners, and their prices tend to fluctuate in line with one another. An increase in the price of sugar represents greater demand for sugar and other sweeteners, such as honey.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Foreign Honey Production is Often Less-Costly
international_trade_points.trade_description: Compared to domestic operations, the domestic industry does not receive any special price supports similar to the sugar supply chain. This permits foreign producers, whose input costs and prices may be lower, to export honey products to the US at a competitive price. Suppliers in Argentina, India and Vietnam are subject to higher average rainfalls, making honey production easier and cost-effective in these regions.

That Have Resulted in a Devaluation of Its Currency. The Argentine Peso has been depreciating against the US dollar, making Argentine beekeeping products more affordable for US importers. The lower cost of Argentine beekeeping products compared to domestic or other imported products is making them more attractive to US importers.

The US faces competition from other countries, such as China, Argentina, and New Zealand, which are major honey-producing nations. Some countries have lower production costs than the US due to lower labor costs and less stringent regulatory requirements. Other countries produce different varieties of honey, such as manuka honey from New Zealand, which has unique health benefits and is in high demand.

The US trade policies, including trade agreements and tariffs, impact the export of beekeeping products. Other countries have imposed tariffs and trade restrictions on US beekeeping products, making it more expensive to export US honey. Trade agreements and policies can either facilitate or hinder access to foreign markets, affecting the volume and value of US beekeeping exports.

Consumers in some countries, such as Japan and Europe, have a preference for high-quality, authentic products, including US honey, which can create market opportunities for US exporters. In some markets, such as China, there is a preference for locally produced honey, which can limit the export opportunities for US producers.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains region has a dry climate, which is ideal for beekeeping, as it reduces the risk of diseases and pests that thrive in humid environments. Beekeepers in North Dakota and South Dakota tend to be migratory, moving their hives south during the winter to avoid freezing temperatures.

The Southeast region has a mild climate, which allows bees to forage throughout the year and supports high honey production. A long growing season supports high agricultural production, including crops that rely on bees for pollination, like blueberries, melons and cucumbers, providing beekeepers with an abundant source of income from pollination services.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Apiary inspections are generally performed by state-run departments to prevent the introduction and establishment of pests, diseases and invasive species. State government regulations may include a requirement to register beehives and ensure the site is accessible for inspection, while also regulating the movement and entry of bees and all methods of disease treatments.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002
regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the act, facilities that manufacture, process, pack or store food in the United States, including honey, must register with the US Food and Drug Administration. A permit from the US Department of Agriculture is required for the importation of live bees, dead bees, used bee boards, hives and nests, beeswax, pollen and honey for bee feed.

The US Department of Commerce has imposed several antidumping duties on honey imports from Argentina and China. The American Honey Producers Association and the Sioux Honey Association Co-op complained that the industry was being hurt by the sale of honey from these countries at a less than fair value. Antidumping and countervailing duties were imposed as a result.

basis_points.basis_description: The Beekeeping industry is highly fragmented. It is primarily made up of a large number of small farms and a few larger operations and cooperatives. Many beekeepers are owner-operators that devote productive resources to other farming activities. As such, no individual honey producer accounts for more than 5.0% of industry revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The beekeeping industry is composed of numerous small-scale operators, and the diversity of products makes it challenging for any single player to dominate the market.
Beekeeping is a relatively low-cost enterprise that can be started by anyone with basic equipment and knowledge.

Beekeeping is often carried out on a small scale, with production focused on specific regions or areas. This makes it challenging for large-scale operators to establish a dominant position in the market.
Most beekeepers have limited capacity to produce honey, making it challenging to compete with larger producers that can produce honey throughout the year.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit fluctuations are brought on by varying weather patterns, numbers of colonies and disease outbreaks.
Wages have increased to retain employees and keep up with demand from consumers and businesses. Wage costs are expected to account for 27.5% of industry revenue in 2023, up from 18.8% in 2018.

Purchase costs vary from year to year, sometimes even season to season. Purchase costs account for 25.5% of industry revenue in 2023. This category includes essential items, such as beehives and bee feed, medicines and repairs.

Rent is typically low, since most farmers own their land. Rent costs are expected to account for 2.6% of industry revenue in 2023. This cost includes rental payments for leased land and lease payment of equipment.

Depreciation costs are higher for larger operations. Aside from the bees themselves, equipment for building hives is the largest material input. Depreciation on the cost of frames, storage containers and other equipment accounts for 4.8% of industry revenue in 2023.

Utility costs are relatively high for beekeepers. The crystallization process requires heat and increases proportionally to the number of hives a beekeeper has. Bees must be protected from the cold or an early frost, which kill them and ruin a beekeeper's returns. Utility costs account for an estimated 7.9% of industry revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Both the rate of new innovation and the concentration are in line with the average across all industries.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Weather conditions and domestic climates impact production
volatility_points.volatility_description: Honey production varies widely among regions and from year-to-year due to factors like the average annual amount of rainfall, soil conditions, temperature, cropping patterns, management and adverse effects of disease.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Import penetration of honey produced in low-cost developing countries
volatility_points.volatility_description: Import penetration of honey produced in low-cost developing countries, like Argentina and India, has increased.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The price of competing products can influence demand for honey
volatility_points.volatility_description: The price of competing products, like maple syrup, can influence demand for honey.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Favorable conditions in other agricultural pursuits
volatility_points.volatility_description: Favorable conditions in other agricultural pursuits could encourage beekeepers to shift resources away from the industry.
With the onset of colony collapse disease, there is a greater element of uncertainty regarding future honey production.
The COVID-19 pandemic contributed to a severe reduction in demand for both honey and pollination services, due to suppressed consumer demand for agriculture products, reduced revenue 11.6% in 2020.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Per capita consumption of honey has remained relatively constant
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Per capita consumption of honey in the United States has remained relatively constant. Honey is purchased directly by food manufacturers as an ingredient in other food products, and also by consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Domestic honey production accounts for a shrinking portion of consumption
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Domestic honey production accounts for a shrinking portion of consumption as plentiful, lower-cost imports continue to penetrate the domestic market.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Honey production has decreased as a share of industry revenue
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Honey production has decreased as a share of industry revenue over the past five years, primarily like declining honey prices as well as a strong increase in the value of pollination services.

FAQs.question: What is the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002?
FAQs.answer: Under the act, facilities that manufacture, process, pack or store food in the United States, including honey, must register with the US Food and Drug Administration. A permit from the US Department of Agriculture is required for the importation of live bees, dead bees, used bee boards, hives and nests, beeswax, pollen and honey for bee feed.

FAQs.question: What are antidumping and countervailing duties related to honey imports?
FAQs.answer: The US Department of Commerce has imposed several antidumping duties on honey imports from Argentina and China. The American Honey Producers Association and the Sioux Honey Association Co-op complained that the industry was being hurt by the sale of honey from these countries at a less than fair value. Antidumping and countervailing duties were imposed as a result.

FAQs.question: What assistance is available for the honey industry?
FAQs.answer: The Bee Informed Partnership provides technical assistance and training to beekeepers to improve honey bee health, reduce colony losses and increase profitability. The Pollinator Partnership works to protect pollinators like bees through conservation, education and research.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries impacted operations?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports from low-wage countries have increased import competition, siphoning revenue from domestic beekeepers. The prevalence of illegal and illicit honey imports have undercut the domestic market in recent years. Diversifying operations to include pollination services will lessen reliance on honey sales.

FAQs.question: How have companies hedged against volatile honey prices during COVID-19?
FAQs.answer: Apiculturists that enter into long-term supply agreements will exhibit stable revenue due to contracted rates, giving them downside protection. Furthermore, with an expected level of income, farmers can also redeploy resources to diversify products sold, such as queen bees and wax.

FAQs.question: How do companies protect against volatile fuel prices?
FAQs.answer: Beekeepers that provide pollination services for key local clients will have reduced fuel purchase costs, widening margins. Beekeepers who sell honey and beeswax locally will exhibit lower fuel costs, benefitting profit margins. Furthermore, beekeepers who enter into long-term purchasing agreements will lock in prices protecting themselves from upside risk.

FAQs.question: How do companies protect against volatile market activity during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: The industry has exhibited volatile returns over the past five years, making supply chain management difficult. Declining honey yields and colony numbers have caused high levels of volatility in honey prices.

FAQs.question: Have companies used drones to monitor hives and colonies?
FAQs.answer: With the Federal Aviation Administration allowing the use of commercial drones, labor can be saved by monitoring colonies remotely. Beekeeping is notoriously labor-intensive, and this represents a significant opportunity to leverage capital developments.

FAQs.question: Have companies innovated labor-saving solutions?
FAQs.answer: Beekeeping is notoriously labor-intensive, with wages on the rise. As a result, this suggests the industry should shift towards a more capital-intensive model in the meantime.

FAQs.question: Have international tariffs affected imports or exports?
FAQs.answer: The US government has cracked down on the importation of illicit honey from countries such as China and Argentina, benefitting domestic beekeepers. It is illegal to import live bees, and permitting is required to import dead bees and beeboards.

FAQs.question: How do farms ensure compliance with organic and labeling regulations?
FAQs.answer: Organic produce trades at a significant premium over traditional honey. However, labeling honey as organic, or as any other type of flower or type or grade disingenuously entails heavy fines. Honey fraud is frowned upon.

FAQs.question: How do company profit margins compare to competitors?
FAQs.answer: Beekeepers that can trim labor costs through the hiring of seasonal labor will exhibit wider profit margins. Beekeepers that can ensure a steady supply of inputs and consistent production will have reduced purchase costs, benefitting profit margins.

FAQs.question: What challenges does the industry face financing operations?
FAQs.answer: Returns for beekeepers tend to follow fluctuations in the agricultural sector at large, inhibiting certainty of returns. Government payments have made up the largest share of net sector income now than ever recorded. Farms are facing a liquidity crisis, with government payments accounting for nearly 50.0% of sector net income in 2020.

FAQs.question: How do beekeepers ensure colony health and wellbeing?
FAQs.answer: Honeybee populations have been devastated by colony collapse disorder, a problem that has been abating but has caused a significant slowdown in the rate of increase in hives and apiculturists. As bees become more limited, the price of pollination services and honey will rise.

FAQs.question: Have beekeepers adopted a commercial focus?
FAQs.answer: Pollination services rather than honey sales have become the industry's most profitable and most abundant segment. Operators who rent out their hives to almond groves and other agricultural producers for pollination of crops will succeed very well.

FAQs.question: How do beekeepers maintain product quality?
FAQs.answer: Operators must work to ensure that their products are of high quality, more specifically since organic produce and other artisanal goods trade at a premium and will garner more revenue per sale.

FAQs.question: Do companies promote honey as an alternative to sugar?
FAQs.answer: As consumption of sugar and sweeteners, including syrups, such as honey, increases, demand for industry products rises as well. Promoting the health benefits of honey over sugar via an ad campaign can increase industry sales.

FAQs.question: Are certain products more sensitive to fluctuations in disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. Typically, as income rises consumers will trade up for higher-margin products such as organic or specific flower honey.

FAQs.question: Do beekeepers conduct pollination services?
FAQs.answer: Beekeepers have turned to pollinate crops amid a shortage of honey bees into their most profitable and largest segment. Overall, pollination services have surpassed honey for the first time in 2019.
